steps.text: Identify potential fire risks in working machines.
Evaluate each machine's operating environment and conditions.
Issue clear instructions for safety.
Supervise compliance with safety instructions.
Assess fire risks by considering impact on company's other risks, level of risk taken, employee actions in an accident, adequacy of preventive maintenance, and daily work management.
Begin fire timeline when machine is put into service.
Perform scheduled maintenance according to manufacturer's instructions.
Participate in manufacturer recall campaigns.
Inspect and clean engine compartment and surroundings daily in dusty or fire-hazard conditions.
Inspect and clean engine compartment and surroundings weekly in other environments.
Use authentic replacement parts from known manufacturers.
Shut down engine before inspecting for fuel leaks.
Check joints of hoses and pipes for fuel leaks.
Inspect electrical systems at least once a year.
Use multimeter to measure voltage drops in electrical systems.
Inspect cables not protected by a fuse several times a year.
Check battery compartment for sufficient ventilation.
Check electric panel during maintenance.
Repair any redundant or hanging wires in the electric panel.
Ensure fuse boxes are intact and have lids.
Check cable harnesses in the high-vibration engine compartment.
Fasten cables with brackets no more than 150 mm apart.
Attach fasteners and cable ties that can withstand temperatures of 120°C.
Firmly attach alternator with correct belt tension and terminal covers.
Clean alternator filter to prevent overheating.
Check for anomalies with a thermal camera.
Inspect exhaust pipe for leaks and ensure all thermal shields are in place.
Prevent contamination during refuelling of urea systems and diesel particulate filter.
Ensure regeneration occurs in a safe outdoor environment away from flammable materials.
Delay regeneration if the machine is in a fire-hazard environment.
Do not leave the machine unattended during regeneration.
Inspect all hoses in the swivelling joint.
Check engine compartment has at least 3L extinguishing agent per cubic meter.
Install detection system covering entire engine compartment.
Connect detection system to non-fused cables.
Obtain certificate for installation.
Perform annual servicing.
Clean engine compartments daily.
Shut down engine in case of fire.
Cut electricity from main power switch.
Call for help.
Perform first-aid fire extinguishing.
Confirm fire is out with fire department.
Report all accidents and dangerous situations to a supervisor immediately.
Stop and leave the machine in place if possible.
Prevent further damage and minimize injuries.
Wear protective clothing and a helmet.
Use a hands-free device for phone calls.
Wear a safety belt.
Use stepladders and handrails, maintaining three points of contact when climbing.
Keep doors closed during operation.
Ensure tools are secure and emergency exits are marked.
Repair any malfunctions that could lead to an accident without delay.
Arrange practical training on accident and fire procedures.
Check cables and fasteners for security, heat resistance, insulation, and lead-throughs.
Inspect fuses and batteries for condition of non-fused cables and terminal covers.
Clean engine and heater compartments.
Check availability, markings, and operator training for first-aid extinguishing equipment.

constraints.text: Working machines must be evaluated for fire risks based on their operating environment and conditions.
Flammable liquids like hydraulic oil, diesel fuel, and motor oil pose a fire risk when hot surfaces reach about 240°C.
Repair any deviations in fuel leaks and electrical systems immediately.
Intact terminal covers for cables to prevent overheating.
Engine compartment must have sufficient extinguishing agent.
Detection system must cover entire engine compartment.
Detection system must be connected to non-fused cables.
Engine compartments must be cleaned daily.
